sols_html:
Let \(u = 1 + \sin x\) so that \(du = \cos x dx\). Further, notice that

\(u(\pi/2) = 1 + \sin(\pi/2) = 1 + 1 = 2\)

and that

\(u(0) = 1 + \sin(0) = 1 + 0 = 1\).

This gives

\(\int_{0}^{\pi/2}\frac{\cos x}{1 + \sin x}\, dx = \int_{1}^{2}\frac{du}{u} = \left.(\ln|u|)\right|_{1}^{2} = \ln(2) - \ln(1) = \ln(2)\)
